head.title: Connecting the Dots: Oil and Terror

hedline.hl1: Connecting the Dots: Oil and Terror

abstract.p: Norbert C Furumo letter applauds Oct 7 Thomas L Friedman Op-Ed column; contends conserving oil will also fight global warming; urges Pres Bush to rethink his stand on Kyoto Protocol; drawing

block.p: Thomas L. Friedman makes an eye-opening connection between America's habitual need for oil, its indirect financial support for terrorism and the prevention of beneficial changes in places like Saudi Arabia, Syria and Iran.
In addition, don't forget that America's continued increase in consumption of oil is altering the composition of the earth's atmosphere, which will continue to change unpredictably.

Thomas L. Friedman makes an eye-opening connection between America's habitual need for oil, its indirect financial support for terrorism and the prevention of beneficial changes in places like Saudi Arabia, Syria and Iran.
In addition, don't forget that America's continued increase in consumption of oil is altering the composition of the earth's atmosphere, which will continue to change unpredictably.
If there was ever a time to begin vigorous programs to conserve oil and to explore or invent alternatives, it is now.
It is shameful that previous administrations could have put us ahead of the curve on this problem but instead ignored the realities of global warming and global terrorism.
The Bush administration needs to rethink its stand on the Kyoto Protocol and study other countries' approach to energy conservation.
Norbert C. Furumo Charleston, Ill., Oct. 7, 2004
